title: Jindřich Wankel
text:
Jindřich Wankel (<a href="German%20language">German</a>: Heinrich Wankel; July 15, 1821, <a href="Prague">Prague</a> – April 5, 1897, <a href="Olomouc">Olomouc</a>) was a <a href="Bohemia">Bohemia</a>n <a href="palaeontologist">palaeontologist</a> and <a href="archaeologist">archaeologist</a>.
Wankel was born to Damian Wankel, a clerk, and his wife Magdalena, née Schwarz in a bilingual environment. He was attending German schools in Prague and later studied Medicine at the <a href="Charles%20University%20in%20Prague">University of Prague</a> as a student of <a href="Josef%20Hyrtl">Josef Hyrtl</a>.
He came to work into area of <a href="Moravian%20Karst">Moravský kras</a> ("Moravian Karst", today <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech Republic</a>) in 1847 and since 1849 lived in <a href="Blansko">Blansko</a> as a medical doctor. He started with geological exploration of the area and later with <a href="palaeontology">palaeontology</a>, archaeology and anthropology.
In 1850, in Blansko, he set up first ever laboratory to research fossil bones from <a href="Cenozoic%20Era">Cenozoic Era</a> where he assembled complete skeleton of <a href="cave%20bear">cave bear</a> (until then such bones were used for <a href="spodium">spodium</a> in nearby sugar refinery <a href="http%3A//www.boskowan.com/region/sloupsko/wankel.htm"></a>). His most famous discovery (1872) was burial site of a nobleman from <a href="Bronze%20Age">Bronze Age</a> at "<a href="B%C3%BD%C4%8D%C3%AD%20sk%C3%A1la%20Cave">Býčí skála</a>", with skeletons of 40 ritually killed young women (<a href="http%3A//www.showcaves.com/english/cz/caves/ByciSkala.html"></a>, <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20051224100103/http%3A//www.moravskykras.net/byciskala.html"></a>).
His grandson <a href="Karel%20Absolon">Karel Absolon</a> was also famous archaeologist and worked in the same area.
